In 2017, when the Supreme Court ruled that devolved national assemblies such as Scotland's parliament could not veto Brexit, the demands grew louder.
Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said her government at Holyrood would "reset" its timetable on independence to focus on delivering a "soft Brexit."
The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats at Westminster the following year, overtaking the Liberal Democrats to become the third-largest party in the U.K. overall.

But because Scotland only contains 8.4% of the U.K.'s population, its vote to Remain (along with that of Northern Ireland, which accounts for just 2.8% of the U.K.'s population) was vastly outweighed by support for Brexit in England and Wales.
